Hello Wesley-

I also apologize for the delay. I have been traveling a lot recently and am
finally able to catch up on emails.

In my GECCO 2009 paper that Ken mentioned, I also represented the same
problem (evolving gaits for simulated quadrupeds) in one, two and three
dimensions. 

The approach I took may give you some ideas for representing your problem in
three or more dimensions.

I found that a 3D representation did not beat a 2D one (although both the 3D
and 2D representation statistically beat the 1D one by the end of the run).
So you may not find any performance improvements by adding dimensions (as
opposed to representing different kinds of inputs within a lower
dimensionality). However, I did not try putting different *types* of input
information in different dimensions.
 
I would be interested to hear your experience with representing your problem
in 3(+)D, especially if you are able to compare it to alternate
representations (e.g. 2D) or setups (e.g. the r(x) idea).

Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...




> From: Wesley Tansey <tansey@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Mon, 29 Jun 2009 19:31:16 -0700
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] GECCO 2008 Multiagent Paper Question
> 
> Hi everyone,
> 
> I am working on a project that needs a substrate of more than 2
> dimensions. Looking at David and Ken's GECCO'08 paper, I would have
> expected a 3d substrate for the heterogeneous agent experiment. Is there
> some insight I'm missing behind using the special r(x) function rather
> than making a 3rd dimension?
> 
> Wesley
